Posts.Title: Good News!! rosasmommy KentuckyMom

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 07:09PM Bethie1 wrote: Hi-- I finished radiation Aug 14, 2009, and my skin was red, raw, peeling faster than healing, and it will do that as you're getting sunburned basically at a higher level.   I had to get a break from radiation because of this, and had AQUAPHOR put on----this is a vaseline based ointment to promote healing on the raw skin.  My new skin was coming in faster than the old skin could keep up, but the green snotty stuff sounds like infection--call your radiation oncologist and see what they have to say.  I wouldn't play around with it as your immune system will be down for about a year after diagnosis--at least that's my doctors told me.  You can't afford an infection now with a compromised immune system.,  Take care and keep us posted
Posts.Title: Rads burn peeling and seeping yellow/greenish snot looking stuff buccaneersdj Bethie1

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2009 07:15PM Bethie1 wrote: Hey Ladies!!! My name is Beth Hanley, and I'm from the Feb 2009 chemo group and June 2009 rads group! If I may offer any advice, it's to get plenty of water in you.  Chemo dehydrates you.  You'll most likely be told also NOT to eat RAW vegetables--due to the pesticide residue. Your tastebuds may be altered--spag sauce tasted like metal to me--I also had the feeling of metal in my mouth.  I was able to feel better once I ate, but if rinsing your mouth out with mouthwash helps--do that.  Don't overdue your normal routine-when you feel tired, fatigue, or whatever get rest. Putting feet up on couch worked best for me For rads, it'll look and feel like a sunburn.  I used Aquaphor ointment to help with the healing process. I also had more fatigue and slight arthritic feeling with rads-and taking an Advil/Ibuprofen is sufficient for this.  You'll also feel the effects of chemo and rads after your done with everything as it'll take awhile for the effect to get out of your system.  Above all I send hugs to my "sisters". Hope this advice helped!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo June 2009 zuzeee zuzeee

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2010 07:36PM Bethie1 wrote: Hey Sue!!!!  My skin broke down also from the right side of right breast area and all of my underarm area.  I was scheduled for 33 rad treatments, and got them in, but the breakdown of the skin faster than it was healing caused me to have a week off--they just extended my treatment 1 week longer because of the breakdown.  I used Aquaphor vaseline based ointment, and my sister gobbed it on me to make sure it would soak in, and about 3/4's of it did.  It worked wonders, and was recommended by my rad onc. If any of you ladies are having this issue, get some of this ointment.

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 04:16PM - edited Jan 29, 2009 04:18PM by Bethie1 Pam,  I'm newly diagnosed as of 2 weeks ago, and discussed with my doctor all the options.  I had to have a mastectomy vs a lumpectomy attempt that failed because too many lymph nodes were affected, but I'm here!!!! You're right to be angry, scared, fearful, and confused as to where to get information, as it's very overwhelming!! My sister personally found alot of information on this site of breastcancer.org, but she also asked my team of doctors questions, such as how big is tumor, what grade is it, (grade is different from stage and is used to determine how aggressive the cancer is--correct me if I'm wrong anyone).  You've had several tests done already: mammo, x-ray, biopsy, etc.  and from what they see on these tests, the pathology report will come about.  This pathology report will help the doctor to determine what type chemo and/or radiation to give you.  The results of the biopsy which will be before the pathology report will tell the doctor what type of cancer you have, as well as grade, size, and exact location in the breast of tumor.  The grade and size of tumor, and whether or not lymph nodes are affected will determine stage. I would say fight cancer with all your heart and might.  Get all the information you can, don't be afraid to ask questions, most importantly don't assume anything.  Kick this thing right in the bud, tell it where to go, how to get there, and what time to leave.  Also, if need be, get a health care proxy set up, just in case you feel you won't be able to make your own medical decisions. My family had them in place when we admitted our parents to nursing homes, (they're no longer with us), and one is in place for my sister to make my medical decisions.  It can later be revoked after you're better.  Good luck, and let me know how you progress.

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 04:11AM Bethie1 wrote: Hey everyone!!!  I too had radiation burns-so much so that my skin broke down from the burns and I had to have a week off so it could heal!  I was told to gently pat the skin with gauze pads wet with an irrigation solution they gave me a script for as well as to apply Aquaphor. The week off and applying these meds worked wonders!!! In the normal course of treatment, your skin will look like sunburn, be dry and itchy, but try not to scratch--that was where I went wrong. I tried not to scratch, so I rubbed with my T-shirt, and aggravated that broken skin.  It's all healed now! If any of you need an "ear" I'm here as I've been there.  I'm a month out of rads

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2010 05:49PM Bethie1 wrote: Hey Kim--My name is Beth, and I'm a year out from this dreaded disease in August.  My cancer was IDC, 2cm, 5/24 nodes involved.  I had chemo of adriamyacin/cytoxin, and radiation because of lymph node involvement.  That was fine with me because when I found my lump--it was by accident--I scratched myself in the right place at the right time.  I wasn't due for a mammogram, so I had no baseline to go by.  I would've had it this year, but no such luck. Everyone's cicumstance is different--with me the doctor told me that even with chemo and rads there's a 10 % chance of cancer reoccurrence in your lifetime. I don't know if that's me personally or everyone who is diagnosed and he  was just generally speaking. Hope this helps!
Posts.Title: Just curious - who had a mx and still had to have rads? Houndmommy LisaSec

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2009 08:55PM Bethie1 wrote: Hello July girls!!!! I took 4 AC and 4 Taxol. I was very fortunate/blessed/lucky if you will to get through most if not all my chemo treatments. I finished chemo 5/20, and in the process of radiation now.  I have a wonderful group of doctors, and anytime you notice anything different with your body mention it to the doctor.  I was on SO many antinausea drugs with chemo that for the most part I did OK.  I had a generic vesion of Kytril if needed, but for the most part felt fatigue and queasy--nothing that soup and crackers couldn't handle. I of course lost my hair-all of it--but didn't have to shave my legs WOOHOO!!! Chemo is cumulative so as you progress in your treatment you'll feel your symptoms more.  If you ladies are able to have something to eat while doing chemo--do it!! I had a lunch provided by the hospital, and it helped me with my nausea. Also, my hydration day was the day after chemo-keep drinking water EVEN AFTER  chemo.  I became dehydrated last week after radiation because I forgot I wasn't getting the hydration I had during chemo.  Also, if any of you are taking taxol for your chemo, you may be given Benadryl intravenously. I had this therapy, and had a jittery/shakiness/shivery feeling from the benadryl. Not the reaction I was supposed to have.  Apparently it was too much for my system, if it works for you fine--if not ask if you can take OVER-THE-COUNTER Benadryl.  I took the over-the-counter type, 1 hour before  chemo, then another one right before the nurses administered chemo--and I slept like a baby!!! Also when you ladies go through radiation--use 100% aloe vera to start when you begin your radiations BEFORE YOU SEE RED.  My sister recommended I do this, and I haven't been feeling my sunburn; I just look burnt. Another thing, as you do your radiation treatments you MAY see black dots/freckles--I did. I asked rad onc about the one I had, and it was a radiation tattoo, so don't be alarmed,  but by all means mention anything and everything you see different on your bodies.  Hope my experience helps you!!
